conflictDescription: User Story A wants to use voice commands to ask clients politely and respect privacy before acting, while User Story B requires ALFRED to give frequent voice reminders that interrupt users often. These two impose opposite behaviors on voice interaction, as one forbids frequent interruptions and the other demands them.
userStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want to use voice commands to ask clients if they feel unwell, so I can respect their privacy and get their clear permission before acting.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to give smart voice reminders that interrupt users often, so I can improve adherence even if users do not like it.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to balance privacy respect and necessary reminders by making voice reminders less frequent and permission-based, ensuring polite interaction without frequent interruptions.
newUserStoryASummary: As an informal caregiver, I want ALFRED to ask clients politely for permission before acting, so I can respect their privacy.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want ALFRED to give smart voice reminders only when needed, so users are reminded without frequent interruptions.

conflictDescription: User Story A wants to block non-medical features during caregiver shifts, while User Story B wants to force strict reminders and block user overrides in all cases. These impose opposing instructions on system behavior regarding blocking and control, creating a start-forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block all non-medical features during my work hours so I can focus only on clinical care without distractions.
userStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to force strict reminders and block user overrides, so users follow care routines and do not break workflows.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to allow blocking non-medical features during caregiver shifts while allowing strict reminders and blocking overrides only outside caregiver shifts, creating a context-aware control.
newUserStoryASummary: As a medical caregiver, I want ALFRED to block non-medical features during my work hours, so I can focus on clinical care without distractions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As a developer, I want to enforce strict reminders and block user overrides outside caregiver shifts, so users follow care routines effectively.
